title: RetiredCoder
author: RetiredCoder
content: Guys, let's have some fun again, I have one more mini-puzzle for you There is 0.01 BTC on that address, so hurry up!03C8F139DAD58B4786D3649992849733C2A7626F011089E87508CCDF8B0758C493Hint: It's a strong point so you cannot solve it by kangaroos. But it's a special point, you can solve it easily if you use some feature of secp256k1.PS. No BS here please, I will remove it.PPS. For history, previous mini-puzzle is here: https://bitcointalk.org/index.php?topic=5522785

comments.author: llenn1227
comments.body: Quote from: RetiredCoder on January 14, 2025, 05:22:30 PMGuys, let's have some fun again, I have one more mini-puzzle for you There is 0.01 BTC on that address, so hurry up!03C8F139DAD58B4786D3649992849733C2A7626F011089E87508CCDF8B0758C493Hint: It's a strong point so you cannot solve it by kangaroos. But it's a special point, you can solve it easily if you use some feature of secp256k1.PS. No BS here please, I will remove it.PPS. For history, previous mini-puzzle is here: https://bitcointalk.org/index.php?topic=5522785That's Sad, a hard one QAQBut i'll try my best Here's the address - > https://www.blockchain.com/explorer/addresses/btc/1AH5pRZW4ZofEJhdb3muNZ1q88YNu3Rez7

comments.author: RetiredCoder
comments.body: Quote from: llenn1227 on January 14, 2025, 05:23:52 PMThat's Sad, a hard one QAQBut i'll try my best It's not difficult, really  And you don't even need GPUs or fast PC.

comments.author: llenn1227
comments.created_time: January 14, 2025, 05:30:19 PMLast edit: January 14, 2025, 06:31:28 PM by llenn1227
comments.body: Quote from: RetiredCoder on January 14, 2025, 05:26:13 PMQuote from: llenn1227 on January 14, 2025, 05:23:52 PMThat's Sad, a hard one QAQBut i'll try my best It's not difficult, really  And you don't even need GPUs or fast PC.I think i need a better brain.For a pool guy who failed 4 subject in this semester.Maybe I need to study whole ECDSA for the next puzzle?

comments.author: RetiredCoder
comments.body: Quote from: llenn1227 on January 14, 2025, 05:30:19 PMMaybe I need to study whole ECDSA for the next puzzle?ECDSA already was in previous puzzle, so probably I won't use it again

comments.author: llenn1227
comments.body: Quote from: RetiredCoder on January 14, 2025, 06:58:05 PMQuote from: llenn1227 on January 14, 2025, 05:30:19 PMMaybe I need to study whole ECDSA for the next puzzle?ECDSA already was in previous puzzle, so probably I won't use it again  That a good news!But first i need to figure this puzzle out.I guess this might have something to do with the mirrored curve?Or maybe the constant of secp256k1?Still learning how this work Orz

comments.author: iceland2k14
comments.body: Quote from: RetiredCoder on January 14, 2025, 05:26:13 PMIt's not difficult, really  And you don't even need GPUs or fast PC.None of the Endo/Sym points are below 53 bitsNone of the Endo/Sym points are within 30 bits of the bit boundary from 1 to 256None of the Endo/Sym points are a hash of "Mini-puzzle #4" or "RetiredCoder Mini-puzzle #4"None of the Endo/Sym points are a close to the privatekey or K or previous #3 PuzzleC'mon Guys. do it fast. What else...

comments.author: RetiredCoder
comments.body: No worries, I will give a new hint after 24 hours. But I still think that you will solve it earlier

comments.author: hskun
comments.body: not the p n endo lambda beta...it was solved...so sad...

comments.author: RetiredCoder
comments.body: Another explanation:It's a special point, if you apply endomorphism for it, you will get previous point (Point - G).It's funny to have two points next to each other with same Y, isn't it?  And since you know the distance between these two points, you can calculate the private key easily.Congrats to the winner!

comments.author: JDScreesh
comments.body: Hello there  Congratulations to the winner  I think I'm lost with this red part of the explanation:Quote from: RetiredCoder on January 15, 2025, 10:27:05 AMAnother explanation:It's a special point, if you apply endomorphism for it, you will get previous point (Point - G).It's funny to have two points next to each other with same Y, isn't it?  And since you know the distance between these two points, you can calculate the private key easily.Congrats to the winner! I'm trying to get the privkey with this information, but I think I'm missing something  Thanks for all the learning  Greetings.

comments.author: Major Azul
comments.body: hello, where can I learn how to decode this? and what is the address?

comments.author: RetiredCoder
comments.body: Quote from: JDScreesh on January 15, 2025, 10:54:56 AMI'm trying to get the privkey with this information, but I think I'm missing something  Thanks for all the learning  Greetings.Sure!  We know:lambda * x = a [mod N]x = a + 1 [mod N]So:lambda * (a + 1) = a [mod N]lambda * a + lambda = a [mod N](lambda - 1) * a + lambda = 0 [mod N]a = -lambda / (lambda - 1) [mod N]

comments.author: JDScreesh
comments.body: Quote from: RetiredCoder on January 15, 2025, 11:06:49 AMSure!  We know:lambda * x = a [mod N]x = a + 1 [mod N]So:lambda * (a + 1) = a [mod N]lambda * a + lambda = a [mod N](lambda - 1) * a + lambda = 0 [mod N]a = -lambda / (lambda - 1) [mod N]Cool! now I can see it  Thanks a lot for the explanation

comments.author: JDScreesh
comments.body: Quote from: mjojo on January 15, 2025, 11:34:12 AMsame Y coordinate from two point, but still don't know how to calculate Lam 37718080363155996902926221483475020450927657555482586988616620542887997980018I got lambda value searching... and found it in Hal Finney's post "Speeding up signature verification" ( https://bitcointalk.org/index.php?topic=3238.0 )The lambda and beta values in that post are in hexadecimal.lambda = 0x5363ad4cc05c30e0a5261c028812645a122e22ea20816678df02967c1b23bd72beta = 0x7ae96a2b657c07106e64479eac3434e99cf0497512f58995c1396c28719501ee

comments.author: mjojo
comments.body: Quote from: JDScreesh on January 15, 2025, 11:48:54 AMQuote from: mjojo on January 15, 2025, 11:34:12 AMsame Y coordinate from two point, but still don't know how to calculate Lam 37718080363155996902926221483475020450927657555482586988616620542887997980018I got lambda value searching... and found it in Hal Finney's post "Speeding up signature verification" ( https://bitcointalk.org/index.php?topic=3238.0 )The lambda and beta values in that post are in hexadecimal.lambda = 0x5363ad4cc05c30e0a5261c028812645a122e22ea20816678df02967c1b23bd72beta = 0x7ae96a2b657c07106e64479eac3434e99cf0497512f58995c1396c28719501ee  thank you

comments.author: iceland2k14
comments.body: Code:import secp256k1 as icepub = '03C8F139DAD58B4786D3649992849733C2A7626F011089E87508CCDF8B0758C493'lmda = 0x5363ad4cc05c30e0a5261c028812645a122e22ea20816678df02967c1b23bd72N = ice.NG = ice.scalar_multiplication(1)Q = ice.pub2upub(pub)   # pvkQE = ice.pub_endo1(Q)   # pvk * lmda % NQG = ice.point_subtraction( Q, G )  # pvk -1 if QG == QE:    # pvk -1 = (pvk * lmda % N)    # pvk -1 = (pvk * lmda % N)    # pvk - pvk * lmda = 1 %N    # pvk (1 - lmda) = 1  %N    # pvk = 1 / (1 - lmda)  %N    print(f'[+] PrivateKey: {hex(pow((1-lmda), N-2, N))}')Code:[+] PrivateKey: 0xc6768f199574104ae1b75eab82b0cc1d2d2e9ee7d50637a574e27131e9301552I missed it indeed.

comments.author: RetiredCoder
comments.body: Quote from: iceland2k14 on January 15, 2025, 12:09:39 PMCode:[+] PrivateKey: 0xc6768f199574104ae1b75eab82b0cc1d2d2e9ee7d50637a574e27131e9301552I missed it indeed. SadCorrect!You are already the winner of another mini-puzzle so don't be sad
